title: 111_hr3620
content: The "Hiring Heroes Tax Incentive Act of 2009" allows employers to receive a credit for hiring members of the Ready Reserve, National Guard, and veterans recently separated from the Armed Forces. The Hiring Heroes Tax Incentive Act of 2009 allows employers to claim a 15 percent military employment credit for qualified wages paid to qualified employees, with a limit of $10,000 per employee per year. The Hiring Heroes Tax Incentive Act of 2009 allows employers to claim a 15 percent military employment credit for qualified wages paid to qualified employees, with a limit of $10,000 per employee per year. The qualified employee is defined as an employee whose services are mostly in the employer's trade or business and is either a Ready Reserve-National Guard employee or a recently-separated veteran. The term 'qualified employee' excludes individuals listed in section 1396(d)(2). A 'Ready Reserve-National Guard employee' is a member of the Ready Reserve or National Guard. A 'recently-separated veteran' served in the Armed Forces and was honorably discharged within the past 5 years. The text discusses definitions and rules related to wages, controlled groups, and termination. It also mentions the denial of double benefits and the inclusion of a credit in the general business credit. The text amends section 38 of the Code by adding a new paragraph for the military employment credit. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The text introduces a new credit for employers who hire members of the Ready Reserve, National Guard, and recently separated veterans. The amendments will be effective for taxable years after the enactment of the Act.
